questions.clue: In 1980, this U.S. hockey team defeated the Soviet Union in a game famously called the 'Miracle on Ice'.
In 1936, this African-American athlete won four gold medals at the Berlin Olympics, challenging Nazi ideals of Aryan supremacy.
This Brazilian soccer legend scored his 1,000th goal in 1969, cementing his status as one of the greatest players of all time.
In 1995, this New Zealand rugby team performed the haka before winning the Rugby World Cup, a moment that captured global attention.
In 1964, Japan hosted the Summer Olympics, marking the first time this country hosted the Games, a significant event in sports history.
This soccer anime follows Tsubasa Oozora, a prodigious young player with dreams of winning the World Cup.
In this volleyball anime, the protagonist Shouyou Hinata is inspired to play by a player known as the 'Little Giant.'
This boxing anime tells the story of Joe Yabuki, an orphan who rises to fame in the boxing world.
Ryoma Echizen is a tennis prodigy attending Seishun Academy in this anime series.
This anime features the basketball team Shohoku High School and its rookie player Hanamichi Sakuragi.
This city, once called Edo, is now the bustling capital of Japan, known for its anime culture.
The capital of Brazil was moved from this city to Brasília in 1960.
Once known as Byzantium, this city's name changed after the Ottoman conquest.
Before it became the capital of Pakistan, this city was known as Islamabad's predecessor.
This city was formerly known as Batavia during the Dutch colonial period before becoming the capital of Indonesia.
This force, responsible for keeping planets in orbit and athletes grounded, is still not fully understood at the quantum level.
Despite their prevalence in anime, these brain waves remain a mystery in how they enable consciousness and decision-making.
Often discussed in classic anime, this mysterious substance makes up about 27% of the universe's mass-energy content but remains unseen.
Despite the importance of this process in sports recovery, scientists still can't fully explain why we need it or how it restores our energy.
These theoretical particles, named after a sports term, are hypothesized to travel faster than light, yet remain elusive in experiments.
In 1911, this iconic painting was stolen from the Louvre by an Italian handyman named Vincenzo Peruggia.
This Boston museum suffered a $500 million art heist in 1990, losing works by Vermeer and Rembrandt.
This Dutch post-impressionist's paintings 'The Parsonage Garden at Nuenen' and 'View of the Sea at Scheveningen' were stolen from the Van Gogh Museum in 2002.
In 2004, Edvard Munch's 'The Scream' was brazenly stolen from this Oslo museum during daylight hours.
The 1961 heist at this museum involved the theft of a Goya and a Velázquez, later recovered from an abandoned car.

final.clue: This sport played a major role in the 1986 anime film 'Castle in the Sky', with characters using a unique variation to traverse the floating island of Laputa.
